articles.title: Mystery of King Tut’s jars solved? Yale researchers find opium clues
articles.summary: Traces of opium found inside an ancient alabaster vase suggest drug use was common in ancient Egypt, not rare or accidental. The discovery raises the possibility that King Tut’s famous jars once held opiates valued enough to be buried with pharaohs—and stolen by tomb raiders.
articles.content:
Scientists examining an ancient alabaster vase in the Yale Peabody Museum's Babylonian Collection detected chemical traces of opiates. The Yale Ancient Pharmacology Program (YAPP) says this is the strongest evidence so far that opium use was widespread in ancient Egyptian society.

Andrew J. Koh, YAPP's principal investigator and the study's lead author, said the results also point to a bigger possibility. Similar ancient Egyptian alabaster vessels (all made of calcite mined from the same quarries in Egypt) including several remarkable examples from the tomb of Pharaoh Tutankhamun could also still carry traces of ancient opiates.

"Our findings combined with prior research indicate that opium use was more than accidental or sporadic in ancient Egyptian cultures and surrounding lands and was, to some degree, a fixture of daily life," said Koh, a research scientist at the Yale Peabody Museum. "We think it's possible, if not probable, that alabaster jars found in King Tut's tomb contained opium as part of an ancient tradition of opiate use that we are only now beginning to understand."

The study appeared in the Journal of Eastern Mediterranean Archaeology. It was coauthored by Agnete W. Lassen, associate curator of the Yale Babylonian Collection, and Alison M. Crandall, YAPP's lab manager.

A Vase Linked to Xerxes and Written in Four Ancient Languages

The alabaster vase bears inscriptions in four ancient languages: Akkadian, Elamite, Persian, and Egyptian. The text is dedicated to Xerxes I, who ruled the Achaemenid Empire from 486 to 465 BCE. Centered in Persia, that empire at its peak included Egypt, Mesopotamia, the Levant, Anatolia, and parts of Eastern Arabia and Central Asia.

Another inscription on the vessel is written in Demotic script, a simplified form of ancient Egyptian writing. It states the vase holds about 1,200 millimeters. (It is 22 centimeters tall.) The researchers noted that intact inscribed ancient Egyptian alabaster vessels are extremely rare, likely fewer than 10 in museum collections worldwide.

The team said the origins of these intact vessels are generally uncertain. Even so, the surviving examples appear to span the reigns of Achaemenid emperors Darius, Xerxes, and Artaxerxes, covering 550 to 425 BCE. Yale's vase has been in the Babylonian Collection since shortly after the university established the collection of about 40,000 ancient artifacts in 1911.

How YAPP Studies Ancient Residues in Museum Vessels

YAPP is based at the Peabody Museum and combines ethnography, science, and technology to investigate everyday life thousands of years ago. The group focuses on organic residues left on or inside ancient containers, which can reveal details about diet and lifestyle. To do this work, the program developed methods designed for residues that deteriorate over time and that can be contaminated, whether the objects come from museum collections or recent excavations.

"Scholars tend to study and admire ancient vessels for their aesthetic qualities, but our program focuses on how they were used and the organic substances they contained, knowledge that reveals a great deal of information about the daily lives of ancient peoples, included what they ate, the medicines they used, and how they spent their leisure time," Koh said.

Koh's attention was first drawn to the vase after he noticed dark-brown aromatic material inside it.

Chemical Biomarkers Confirm Opium Compounds

YAPP's testing found strong evidence of noscapine, hydrocotarnine, morphine, thebaine, and papaverine. These compounds are well-known diagnostic biomarkers for opium.

Researchers said the results align with earlier work that identified opiate residues in Egyptian alabaster vessels and Cypriot base-ring juglets. Those items came from a typical tomb in Sedment, Egypt, south of Cairo, believed to belong to a merchant family. That burial dates to the New Kingdom, when the Egyptian empire lasted from the 16th to the 11th century BCE.

Koh said these two discoveries, separated by more than a millennium and connected to different socio-economic groups, make it plausible that opium could be present in the many alabaster vessels found in Tutankhamun's tomb in the Valley of the Kings.

Opium Use Beyond Medicine and Into Ritual Life

Koh noted that historical signals of opium use often go beyond healing and into spiritual or ritual contexts across antiquity, from ancient Mesopotamia to Egypt and through the Aegean. During Tutankhamun's lifetime, for instance, people in Crete were linked to the so-called "poppy goddess" in clearly ritualistic settings. The poppy plant is also referenced in several ancient texts, including the Ebers Papyrus, Hippocrates, Dioscorides's De Materia Medica, and Galen.

King Tut's Tomb, Sticky Residues, and an Unfinished Investigation

Howard Carter, the Egyptologist and archaeologist, discovered Tutankhamun's tomb in November 1922. The find included an enormous collection of artifacts, among them many exquisitely preserved Egyptian alabaster vessels that likely represented the finest available during Tutankhamen's reign, which last from 1,333 to 1,323 BCE.

In 1933, analytical chemist Alfred Lucas, who worked with Carter's team, carried out a limited chemical study of the vessels. Many contained sticky, dark brown, aromatic organic material. Lucas could not identify the substances at the time, but he concluded most were not unguents or perfumes.

"That Lucas questioned whether any of the vessels contained perfumes or unguents at all and did not identify the remaining vessel contents as primarily aromatic in nature is significant given that the prevailing conventions at the time would have pressured him to do so," Koh said.

No additional testing of those organic materials has been done since Lucas' early effort. The vessels (along with most other artifacts from Tutankhamun's tomb) are now housed at the Grand Egyptian Museum in Giza, Egypt.

Looters Targeted the Contents, Not Just the Containers

The researchers said Carter recorded evidence of an ancient looting episode that focused on what was inside the alabaster vessels. Finger marks inside some jars suggest looters tried to scrape out the contents as completely as possible. Many of the looted vessels held the same kind of dark-brown aromatic material that Lucas concluded was not perfume. A small number of jars were not looted and still contain their original contents.

Koh said whatever was stored in these vessels was considered valuable enough to accompany Tutankhamen into the afterlife, and important enough that grave robbers were willing to risk an attempted theft.

He added that it seems unlikely people would have treated ordinary unguents and perfumes of the period as that valuable.

"We now have found opiate chemical signatures that Egyptian alabaster vessels attached to elite societies in Mesopotamia and embedded in more ordinary cultural circumstances within ancient Egypt," Koh said. "It's possible these vessels were easily recognizable cultural markers for opium use in ancient times, just as hookahs today are attached to shisha tobacco consumption. Analyzing the contents of the jars from King Tut's tomb would further clarify the role of opium in these ancient societies."

articles.personality_title: Yale researchers find opium traces in ancient Egyptian vase linked to King Tut
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long studied objects from ancient Egypt, hoping to understand how people lived thousands of years ago. Among these objects are alabaster jars, some found in the tomb of Pharaoh Tutankhamun, but what they once held has been a mystery.

**What happened** – Researchers at Yale University tested an ancient alabaster vase from their museum’s collection and found chemical traces of opium inside. This vase, inscribed with writings from ancient Persia and Egypt, is similar to jars found in King Tut’s tomb. The study suggests that opium use was common in ancient Egyptian society and that some of Tutankhamun’s jars might have contained opium.

**Impact** – This discovery changes how we understand ancient Egyptian life. It shows that opium was not just used occasionally or by special people but was part of daily life, possibly for medicine or rituals. The fact that tomb robbers tried to steal the jar’s contents shows that the material inside was very valuable. This helps historians see how important opium was in ancient times.

**What's next step** – Researchers hope to test the contents of the alabaster jars from King Tut’s tomb directly. Doing this could confirm if those famous jars also held opium and reveal more about how ancient Egyptians used the drug in their culture and ceremonies.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Yale researchers found strong evidence that opium was widely used in ancient Egypt, possibly including the famous jars buried with King Tutankhamun.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des chercheurs de Yale découvrent des traces d’opium dans un vase égyptien ancien lié au roi Toutânkhamon
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient depuis longtemps les objets de l’Égypte ancienne pour mieux comprendre la vie d’autrefois. Parmi ces objets se trouvent des vases en albâtre, certains provenant de la tombe du pharaon Toutânkhamon, mais leur contenu restait un mystère.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’université Yale ont analysé un vase ancien en albâtre de leur musée et ont trouvé des traces chimiques d’opium à l’intérieur. Ce vase, portant des inscriptions en langues anciennes de Perse et d’Égypte, est similaire aux vases découverts dans la tombe de Toutânkhamon. L’étude suggère que l’opium était couramment utilisé dans la société égyptienne ancienne et que certains vases du roi pourraient en contenir.

**Impact** – Cette découverte change notre compréhension de la vie en Égypte ancienne. Elle montre que l’opium n’était pas utilisé seulement occasionnellement ou par des personnes spéciales, mais faisait partie de la vie quotidienne, peut-être pour la médecine ou les rituels. **Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs souhaitent analyser directement le contenu des vases en albâtre de la tombe de Toutânkhamon. Cela permettrait de confirmer si ces célèbres vases contenaient aussi de l’opium et d’en apprendre plus sur son usage dans la culture et les cérémonies anciennes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des chercheurs de Yale ont trouvé la preuve que l’opium était largement utilisé en Égypte ancienne, peut-être même dans les célèbres vases enterrés avec Toutânkhamon.
articles.personality_title_es: Investigadores de Yale encuentran rastros de opio en un antiguo vaso egipcio vinculado al rey Tut
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante mucho tiempo, los científicos han estudiado objetos del antiguo Egipto para entender cómo vivía la gente hace miles de años. Entre estos objetos hay vasos de alabastro, algunos encontrados en la tumba del faraón Tutankamón, pero no se sabía qué contenían.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Yale analizaron un antiguo vaso de alabastro de su museo y hallaron rastros químicos de opio en su interior. Este vaso, con inscripciones en lenguas antiguas de Persia y Egipto, es similar a otros encontrados en la tumba de Tutankamón. El estudio sugiere que el uso de opio era común en la sociedad egipcia antigua y que algunos vasos del rey podrían haber contenido opio.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento cambia la forma en que entendemos la vida en el antiguo Egipto. Muestra que el opio no se usaba solo de vez en cuando o por personas especiales, sino que formaba parte de la vida diaria, tal vez para medicina o rituales. El hecho de que ladrones intentaran robar el contenido del vaso indica que era muy valioso. Esto ayuda a los historiadores a comprender mejor la importancia del opio en esa época.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores esperan analizar directamente el contenido de los vasos de alabastro de la tumba de Tutankamón. Esto podría confirmar si esos famosos vasos también contenían opio y revelar más sobre cómo se usaba en la cultura y ceremonias antiguas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Investigadores de Yale encontraron pruebas claras de que el opio se usaba ampliamente en el antiguo Egipto, posiblemente en los famosos vasos enterrados con Tutankamón.

articles.title: £100 contactless card limit to be lifted
articles.summary: Card providers can decide whether to offer unlimited payments on contactless cards.
articles.content:
£100 contactless card limit to be lifted

5 hours ago Share Save Kevin Peachey Cost of living correspondent Share Save

Getty Images

Millions of people will be able to set their own contactless card payment limits or even have no limit at all, a regulator has confirmed. Banks and card providers will be given the power, from March, to set a maximum - or unlimited - single payment amount without the need to enter a four-digit PIN. But they are also being encouraged by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to allow cardholders to set their own individual limits, or switch off contactless entirely. Some banks already offer this function. The move comes despite the FCA's own survey showing little appetite among consumers and industry respondents for a change from the current £100 limit on contactless cards.

The FCA said it did not expect card providers to make immediate changes to the current limit from March, but they had the flexibility to do so. When contactless card payments were introduced in 2007, the transaction limit was set at £10. The limit was raised gradually, to £15 in 2010, to £20 in 2012, then to £30 in 2015, before the Covid pandemic prompted a jump to £45 in 2020, then to £100 in October 2021.

While contactless cards currently have a £100 payment limit, anyone using their smartphone to pay can spend any amount without the need for a PIN. In-built security features, such as thumbprints and face ID, provide greater protection.

But concerns have been raised about cards becoming more attractive to thieves and fraudsters, when high-value payments can be made with a tap of a card. Various protections are already in place, such as a prompt to enter a PIN after a series of consecutive contactless transactions are made. Consumers would still get their money back if it was stolen by fraudsters, according to David Geale, executive director of payments and digital finance at the FCA. "Contactless is people's favoured way to pay. We want to make sure our rules provide flexibility for the future, and choice for both firms and consumers," he said. Other countries, such as Canada, Australia and New Zealand allow industry to set contactless card limits. Jana Mackintosh, managing director of payments and innovation at UK Finance, which represents banks, said: "Any changes made in the future will be done carefully and ensure strong security and fraud controls remain in place."

Temptation to spend?
articles.reasoning: The article reports a regulatory change allowing consumers more flexibility and control over contactless payment limits, potentially improving convenience and user choice. This change impacts millions of people broadly and includes safeguards against fraud, representing a meaningful positive shift in everyday financial transactions.
articles.personality_title: UK to let banks offer unlimited contactless card payments
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Contactless card payments let people pay by tapping their card without entering a PIN. Since 2007, the UK has gradually increased the limit on how much you can pay this way, reaching £100 in 2021. Right now, this limit is fixed, except for smartphone payments which can be unlimited due to extra security like fingerprint or face ID.

**What happened** – Starting in March, banks and card companies in the UK can choose to remove the £100 limit on contactless card payments. They can allow unlimited single payments without a PIN or let customers decide their own contactless spending limits. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), the UK regulator, supports this change but also encourages banks to keep strong fraud protections and let users turn off contactless payments if they want.

**Impact** – This change gives millions of people more freedom to use their cards in ways that suit them best. For example, someone could pay for a big purchase quickly without entering a PIN. At the same time, safety measures will protect customers from fraud. This approach balances convenience with security, which is important because contactless payments are very popular.

**What's next step** – Banks will decide if and when they want to raise or remove the contactless limit. Consumers might soon have new options to control how much they spend with contactless payments. Regulators and banks will continue working to keep fraud low while making payments easier.

**One-sentence takeaway** – From March, UK banks can let customers pay any amount by tapping their contactless cards, offering more choice and convenience alongside strong fraud protections.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Royaume-Uni autorise les paiements sans contact illimités par carte
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les paiements sans contact permettent de payer en tapotant sa carte sans saisir de code PIN. Depuis 2007, le plafond de paiement sans contact au Royaume-Uni a augmenté progressivement pour atteindre 100 £ en 2021. Actuellement, cette limite est fixe, sauf pour les paiements par smartphone qui peuvent être illimités grâce à des sécurités supplémentaires comme l’empreinte digitale ou la reconnaissance faciale.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – À partir de mars, les banques et les fournisseurs de cartes au Royaume-Uni pourront choisir de supprimer la limite de 100 £ sur les paiements sans contact. Ils pourront autoriser des paiements illimités sans PIN ou permettre aux clients de fixer eux-mêmes leurs plafonds de paiement sans contact. L’Autorité de conduite financière (FCA) soutient ce changement tout en encourageant les banques à maintenir des protections solides contre la fraude et à laisser les utilisateurs désactiver les paiements sans contact s’ils le souhaitent.

**Impact** – Ce changement offre à des millions de personnes plus de liberté pour utiliser leur carte comme elles le souhaitent. Par exemple, quelqu’un pourra payer rapidement un achat important sans saisir de PIN. En même temps, des mesures de sécurité protégeront les clients contre la fraude. Cette approche équilibre commodité et sécurité, ce qui est important car les paiements sans contact sont très populaires.

**Prochaine étape** – Les banques décideront si et quand elles veulent augmenter ou supprimer la limite sans contact. Les consommateurs pourraient bientôt avoir de nouvelles options pour contrôler leurs dépenses sans contact. Les régulateurs et les banques continueront à travailler pour limiter la fraude tout en facilitant les paiements.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Dès mars, les banques britanniques pourront permettre à leurs clients de payer n’importe quel montant en tapotant leur carte sans contact, offrant plus de choix et de commodité avec des protections solides contre la fraude.
articles.personality_title_es: Reino Unido permitirá pagos ilimitados con tarjeta sin contacto
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los pagos sin contacto permiten a las personas pagar tocando su tarjeta sin ingresar un PIN. Desde 2007, el Reino Unido ha aumentado poco a poco el límite para estos pagos, llegando a 100 libras en 2021. Actualmente, este límite es fijo, excepto para pagos con teléfono móvil que pueden ser ilimitados gracias a la seguridad adicional como huellas digitales o reconocimiento facial.

**Qué pasó** – A partir de marzo, los bancos y proveedores de tarjetas en el Reino Unido podrán decidir eliminar el límite de 100 libras para pagos sin contacto. Podrán permitir pagos ilimitados sin PIN o dejar que los clientes establezcan sus propios límites. La Autoridad de Conducta Financiera (FCA) apoya este cambio pero también anima a los bancos a mantener fuertes protecciones contra el fraude y a permitir que los usuarios desactiven los pagos sin contacto si lo desean.

**Impacto** – Este cambio da a millones de personas más libertad para usar sus tarjetas como prefieran. Por ejemplo, alguien podría pagar una compra grande rápidamente sin ingresar un PIN. Al mismo tiempo, habrá medidas de seguridad para proteger a los clientes del fraude. Este equilibrio entre comodidad y seguridad es importante porque los pagos sin contacto son muy populares.

**Próximo paso** – Los bancos decidirán si y cuándo quieren aumentar o eliminar el límite sin contacto. Los consumidores pronto podrían tener nuevas opciones para controlar cuánto gastan con pagos sin contacto. Los reguladores y bancos seguirán trabajando para reducir el fraude mientras facilitan los pagos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Desde marzo, los bancos del Reino Unido podrán permitir que sus clientes paguen cualquier cantidad con tarjeta sin contacto, ofreciendo más opciones y comodidad junto con fuertes protecciones contra el fraude.
